* If fullscreen is enabled and the width or height is not supported (see resize event will be triggered.

* If the fullscreen type is 'desktop', then the window will be automatically resized to the desktop resolution.

* If the width and height is bigger than or equal to the desktop dimensions (this includes setting both to 0) and fullscreen is set to false, it will appear 'visually' fullscreen, but it's not true fullscreen and conf.lua (i.e. t.window = false) and use this function to manually create the window, then you must not call any other love.graphics.* function before this one. Doing so will result in undefined behavior and/or crashes because OpenGL cannot function properly without a window.

* Transparent backgrounds are currently not supported.

functions.name: toPixels

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: A number in density-independent units to convert to pixels.

returns.name: pixelvalue
returns.description: The converted number, in pixels.

returns.name: px
returns.description: The converted x-axis value of the coordinate, in pixels.

returns.name: py
returns.description: The converted y-axis value of the coordinate, in pixels.

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: The x-axis value of a coordinate in density-independent units to convert to pixels.

arguments.name: y
arguments.description: The y-axis value of a coordinate in density-independent units to convert to pixels.

variants.description: The units of love.graphics.getWidth, love.graphics.getHeight, love.mouse.getPosition, mouse events, love.touch.getPosition, and touch events are always in terms of pixels.

functions.description:
Converts a number from density-independent units to pixels.

The pixel density inside the window might be greater (or smaller) than the 'size' of the window. For example on a retina screen in Mac OS X with the highdpi window flag enabled, the window may take up the same physical size as an 800x600 window, but the area inside the window uses 1600x1200 pixels. love.window.toPixels(800) would return 1600 in that case.

This is used to convert coordinates from the size users are expecting them to display at onscreen to pixels. love.window.fromPixels does the opposite. The highdpi window flag must be enabled to use the full pixel density of a Retina screen on Mac OS X and iOS. The flag currently does nothing on Windows and Linux, and on Android it is effectively always enabled.

Most LÃ–VE functions return values and expect arguments in terms of pixels rather than density-independent units.

arguments.name: t

table.name: identity
table.description:
This flag determines the name of the save directory for your game. Note that you can only specify the name, not the location where it will be created:
t.identity = "gabe_HL3" -- Correct

t.identity = "c:/Users/gabe/HL3" -- Incorrect
Alternatively love.filesystem.setIdentity can be used to set the save directory outside of the config file.

table.name: appendidentity
table.description: This flag determines if game directory should be searched first then save directory (true) or otherwise (false)

table.name: version
table.description: t.version should be a string, representing the version of LÃ–VE for which your game was made. It should be formatted as "X.Y.Z" where X is the major release number, Y the minor, and Z the patch level. It allows LÃ–VE to display a warning if it isn't compatible. Its default is the version of LÃ–VE running.

table.name: console
table.description: Determines whether a console should be opened alongside the game window (Windows only) or not. Note: On OSX you can get console output by running LÃ–VE through the terminal.

table.name: accelerometerjoystick
table.description: Sets whether the device accelerometer on iOS and Android should be exposed as a 3-axis Joystick. Disabling the accelerometer when it's not used may reduce CPU usage.

table.name: externalstorage
table.description: Sets whether files are saved in external storage (true) or internal storage (false) on Android.

table.name: gammacorrect
table.description: Determines whether gamma-correct rendering is enabled, when the system supports it.

table.name: audio
mic
table.description: Request microphone permission from the user. When user allows it, love.audio.getRecordingDevices will lists recording devices available. Otherwise, love.audio.getRecordingDevices returns empty table and a message is shown to inform user when called.

table.name: mixwithsystem
table.description: Sets whether background audio / music from other apps should play while LÃ–VE is open. See love.system.hasBackgroundMusic for more details.
Audio options.

table.name: window
title
table.description: Sets the title of the window the game is in. Alternatively love.window.setTitle can be used to change the window title outside of the config file.

table.name: icon
table.description: A filepath to an image to use as the window's icon. Not all operating systems support very large icon images. The icon can also be changed with love.window.setIcon.

table.name: width
table.description: Sets the window's dimensions. If these flags are set to 0 LÃ–VE automatically uses the user's desktop dimensions.

table.name: height
table.description: Sets the window's dimensions. If these flags are set to 0 LÃ–VE automatically uses the user's desktop dimensions.

table.name: borderless
table.description: Removes all border visuals from the window. Note that the effects may wary between operating systems.

table.name: resizable
table.description: If set to true this allows the user to resize the game's window.

table.name: minwidth
table.description: Sets the minimum width and height for the game's window if it can be resized by the user. If you set lower values to window.width and window.height LÃ–VE will always favor the minimum dimensions set via window.minwidth and window.minheight.

table.name: minheight
table.description: Sets the minimum width and height for the game's window if it can be resized by the user. If you set lower values to window.width and window.height LÃ–VE will always favor the minimum dimensions set via window.minwidth and window.minheight.

table.name: fullscreen
table.description: Whether to run the game in fullscreen (true) or windowed (false) mode. The fullscreen can also be toggled via love.window.setFullscreen or love.window.setMode.

table.name: fullscreentype
table.description: Specifies the type of fullscreen mode to use (normal or desktop). Generally the desktop is recommended, as it is less restrictive than normal mode on some operating systems.

table.name: usedpiscale
table.description: Sets whetever to enable or disable automatic DPI scaling.

table.name: vsync
table.description:
Enables or deactivates vertical synchronization. Vsync tries to keep the game at a steady framerate and can prevent issues like screen tearing. It is recommended to keep vsync activated if you don't know about the possible implications of turning it off. Before LÃ–VE 11.0, this value was boolean (true or false). Since LÃ–VE 11.0, this value is number (1 to enable vsync, 0 to disable vsync, -1 to use adaptive vsync when supported).

Note that in iOS, vertical synchronization is always enabled and cannot be changed.

table.name: depth
table.description: The number of bits per sample in the depth buffer (16/24/32, default nil)

table.name: stencil
table.description: Then number of bits per sample in the depth buffer (generally 8, default nil)

table.name: msaa
table.description: The number of samples to use with multi-sampled antialiasing.

table.name: display
table.description: The index of the display to show the window in, if multiple monitors are available.

table.name: highdpi
table.description: See love.window.getPixelScale, love.window.toPixels, and love.window.fromPixels. It is recommended to keep this option disabled if you can't test your game on a Mac or iOS system with a Retina display, because code will need tweaking to make sure things look correct.

table.name: x
table.description: Determines the position of the window on the user's screen. Alternatively love.window.setPosition can be used to change the position on the fly.

table.name: y
table.description: Determines the position of the window on the user's screen. Alternatively love.window.setPosition can be used to change the position on the fly.

It is possible to defer window creation until love.window.setMode is first called in your code. To do so, set t.window = nil in love.conf (or t.screen = nil in older versions.) If this is done, LÃ–VE may crash if any function from love.graphics is called before the first love.window.setMode in your code.

The t.window table was named t.screen in versions prior to 0.9.0. The t.screen table doesn't exist in love.conf in 0.9.0, and the t.window table doesn't exist in love.conf in 0.8.0. This means love.conf will fail to execute (therefore it will fall back to default values) if care is not taken to use the correct table for the LÃ–VE version being used.

Module options.

arguments.description:
The love.conf function takes one argument: a table filled with all the default values which you can overwrite to your liking. If you want to change the default window size, for instance, do:

function love.conf(t)
    t.window.width = 1024
    t.window.height = 768
end

If you don't need the physics module or joystick module, do the following.

function love.conf(t)
    t.modules.joystick = false
    t.modules.physics = false
end

Setting unused modules to false is encouraged when you release your game. It reduces startup time slightly (especially if the joystick module is disabled) and reduces memory usage (slightly).

Note that you can't disable love.filesystem; it's mandatory. The same goes for the love module itself. love.graphics needs love.window to be enabled.

callbacks.description: If a file called conf.lua is present in your game folder (or .love file), it is run before the LÃ–VE modules are loaded. You can use this file to overwrite the love.conf function, which is later called by the LÃ–VE 'boot' script. Using the love.conf function, you can set some configuration options, and change things like the default size of the window, which modules are loaded, and other stuff.

callbacks.name: keypressed

arguments.name: key
arguments.description: Character of the pressed key.

arguments.name: scancode
arguments.description: The scancode representing the pressed key.

arguments.name: isrepeat
arguments.description: Whether this keypress event is a repeat. The delay between key repeats depends on the user's system settings.

variants.description:
Scancodes are keyboard layout-independent, so the scancode 'w' will be generated if the key in the same place as the 'w' key on an American keyboard is pressed, no matter what the key is labelled or what the user's operating system settings are.

Key repeat needs to be enabled with love.keyboard.setKeyRepeat for repeat keypress events to be received. This does not affect love.textinput.

arguments.name: key
arguments.description: Character of the key pressed.

arguments.name: isrepeat
arguments.description: Whether this keypress event is a repeat. The delay between key repeats depends on the user's system settings.

variants.description: Key repeat needs to be enabled with love.keyboard.setKeyRepeat for repeat keypress events to be received.

callbacks.description: Callback function triggered when a key is pressed.

variants.description: Scancodes are keyboard layout-independent, so the scancode 'w' will be used if the key in the same place as the 'w' key on an American keyboard is pressed, no matter what the key is labelled or what the user's operating system settings are.

callbacks.description: Callback function triggered when a keyboard key is released.

callbacks.name: load

arguments.name: arg
arguments.description: Command-line arguments given to the game.

arguments.name: unfilteredArg
arguments.description: Unfiltered command-line arguments given to the executable (see #Notes).

variants.description: In LÃ–VE 11.0, the passed arguments excludes the game name and the fused command-line flag (if exist) when runs from non-fused LÃ–VE executable. Previous version pass the argument as-is without any filtering.

callbacks.description: This function is called exactly once at the beginning of the game.

callbacks.name: lowmemory
callbacks.description:
Callback function triggered when the system is running out of memory on mobile devices.

Mobile operating systems may forcefully kill the game if it uses too much memory, so any non-critical resource should be removed if possible (by setting all variables referencing the resources to '''nil'''), when this event is triggered. Sounds and images in particular tend to use the most memory.

arguments.description: Whether the window has mouse focus or not.

arguments.name: dy

arguments.name: istouch
arguments.description: True if the mouse button press originated from a touchscreen touch-press.

arguments.description: Mouse x position, in pixels.

arguments.name: y
arguments.description: Mouse y position, in pixels.

arguments.name: button
arguments.description: The button index that was pressed. 1 is the primary mouse button, 2 is the secondary mouse button and 3 is the middle button. Further buttons are mouse dependent.

arguments.name: istouch
arguments.description: True if the mouse button press originated from a touchscreen touch-press.

arguments.name: presses
arguments.description: The number of presses in a short time frame and small area, used to simulate double, triple clicks

variants.description: Use love.wheelmoved to detect mouse wheel motion. It will not register as a button press in version 0.10.0 and newer.

callbacks.description: Callback function triggered when a mouse button is pressed.

callbacks.name: resize

arguments.name: w
arguments.description: The new width.

arguments.name: h
arguments.description: The new height.

variants.description:
Calls to love.window.setMode will '''only''' trigger this event if the width or height of the window after the call doesn't match the requested width and height. This can happen if a fullscreen mode is requested which doesn't match any supported mode, or if the fullscreen type is 'desktop' and the requested width or height don't match the desktop resolution.

Since 11.0, this function returns width and height in DPI-scaled units rather than pixels.

callbacks.description: Called when the window is resized, for example if the user resizes the window, or if love.window.setMode is called with an unsupported width or height in fullscreen and the window chooses the closest appropriate size.

callbacks.name: run

returns.name: mainLoop
returns.description: Function which handlers one frame, including events and rendering when called.

returns.name: retval
returns.description: Exit code or error message or nil to continue.

callbacks.description: The main function, containing the main loop. A sensible default is used when left out.

callbacks.name: textedited

arguments.name: text
arguments.description: The UTF-8 encoded unicode candidate text.

arguments.name: start
arguments.description: The start cursor of the selected candidate text.

arguments.name: length
arguments.description: The length of the selected candidate text. May be 0.

callbacks.description:
Called when the candidate text for an IME (Input Method Editor) has changed.

The candidate text is not the final text that the user will eventually choose. Use love.textinput for that.

callbacks.name: textinput

arguments.name: text
arguments.description: The UTF-8 encoded unicode text.

variants.description:
Although Lua strings can store UTF-8 encoded unicode text just fine, many functions in Lua's string library will not treat the text as you might expect. For example, #text (and string.len(text)) will give the number of ''bytes'' in the string, rather than the number of unicode characters. The Lua wiki and a presentation by one of Lua's creators give more in-depth explanations, with some tips.

The utf8 library can be used to operate on UTF-8 encoded unicode text (such as the text argument given in this function.)

On Android and iOS, textinput is disabled by default; call love.keyboard.setTextInput to enable it.

callbacks.description: Called when text has been entered by the user. For example if shift-2 is pressed on an American keyboard layout, the text '@' will be generated.

callbacks.name: touchmoved

arguments.name: id
arguments.description: The identifier for the touch press.

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: The x-axis position of the touch inside the window, in pixels.

arguments.name: y
arguments.description: The y-axis position of the touch inside the window, in pixels.

arguments.name: dx
arguments.description: The x-axis movement of the touch inside the window, in pixels.

arguments.name: dy
arguments.description: The y-axis movement of the touch inside the window, in pixels.

arguments.name: pressure
arguments.description: The amount of pressure being applied. Most touch screens aren't pressure sensitive, in which case the pressure will be 1.

variants.description:
The identifier is only guaranteed to be unique for the specific touch press until love.touchreleased is called with that identifier, at which point it may be reused for new touch presses.

The unofficial Android and iOS ports of LÃ–VE 0.9.2 reported touch positions as normalized values in the range of 1, whereas this API reports positions in pixels.

callbacks.description: Callback function triggered when a touch press moves inside the touch screen.

The unofficial Android and iOS ports of LÃ–VE 0.9.2 reported touch positions as normalized values in the range of 1, whereas this API reports positions in pixels.

functions.name: getVersion

returns.name: major
returns.description: The major version of LÃ–VE, i.e. 0 for version 0.9.1.

returns.name: minor
returns.description: The minor version of LÃ–VE, i.e. 9 for version 0.9.1.

returns.name: revision
returns.description: The revision version of LÃ–VE, i.e. 1 for version 0.9.1.

returns.name: codename
returns.description: The codename of the current version, i.e. 'Baby Inspector' for version 0.9.1.

variants.description:
For LÃ–VE versions below 0.9.1, the following variables can be used instead (and still work in 0.9.2 and newer):

love._version_major

love._version_minor

love._version_revision

functions.description: Gets the current running version of LÃ–VE.

functions.name: hasDeprecationOutput

returns.name: enabled
returns.description: Whether deprecation output is enabled.

functions.description:
Gets whether LÃ–VE displays warnings when using deprecated functionality. It is disabled by default in fused mode, and enabled by default otherwise.

When deprecation output is enabled, the first use of a formally deprecated LÃ–VE API will show a message at the bottom of the screen for a short time, and print the message to the console.

functions.name: isVersionCompatible

arguments.name: version
arguments.description: The version to check (for example '11.3' or '0.10.2').

returns.name: compatible
returns.description: Whether the given version is compatible with the current running version of LÃ–VE.

arguments.name: major
arguments.description: The major version to check (for example 11 for 11.3 or 0 for 0.10.2).

arguments.name: minor
arguments.description: The minor version to check (for example 3 for 11.3 or 10 for 0.10.2).

arguments.name: revision
arguments.description: The revision of version to check (for example 0 for 11.3 or 2 for 0.10.2).

returns.name: compatible
returns.description: Whether the given version is compatible with the current running version of LÃ–VE.

functions.description: Gets whether the given version is compatible with the current running version of LÃ–VE.

functions.name: setDeprecationOutput

arguments.name: enable
arguments.description: Whether to enable or disable deprecation output.

functions.description:
Sets whether LÃ–VE displays warnings when using deprecated functionality. It is disabled by default in fused mode, and enabled by default otherwise.

When deprecation output is enabled, the first use of a formally deprecated LÃ–VE API will show a message at the bottom of the screen for a short time, and print the message to the console.

types.name: Data

functions.name: clone

returns.name: clone
returns.description: The new copy.

functions.description: Creates a new copy of the Data object.

functions.name: getFFIPointer

returns.name: pointer
returns.description: A raw void* pointer to the Data, or nil if FFI is unavailable.

functions.description:
Gets an FFI pointer to the Data.

This function should be preferred instead of Data:getPointer because the latter uses light userdata which can't store more all possible memory addresses on some new ARM64 architectures, when LuaJIT is used.

functions.name: getPointer

returns.name: pointer
returns.description: A raw pointer to the Data.

functions.description: Gets a pointer to the Data. Can be used with libraries such as LuaJIT's FFI.

functions.name: getSize

returns.name: size
returns.description: The size of the Data in bytes.

functions.description: Gets the Data's size in bytes.

functions.name: getString

returns.name: data
returns.description: The raw data.

functions.description: Gets the full Data as a string.

types.description: The superclass of all data.

types.name: Object

functions.name: release

returns.name: success
returns.description: True if the object was released by this call, false if it had been previously released.

functions.description:
Destroys the object's Lua reference. The object will be completely deleted if it's not referenced by any other LÃ–VE object or thread.

This method can be used to immediately clean up resources without waiting for Lua's garbage collector.

functions.name: type

returns.name: type

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: The name of the type to check for.

returns.name: b
returns.description: True if the object is of the specified type, false otherwise.

functions.description: Checks whether an object is of a certain type. If the object has the type with the specified name in its hierarchy, this function will return true.

types.description: The superclass of all LÃ–VE types.
